docs.lead_paragraph: For Ry Russo-Young's sperm donor to claim paternity is offensive, in exactly the same way as adopted children seeking out their ''real'' parents is (Susan Dominus, Oct. 24). As one whose husband was the sperm donor in the conventional way and who went through the months of pregnancy with each child, I am here to say that all that was trivial in determining parenthood. Genetic contribution is the least of it. The ones who change the diapers, hold the foreheads when the children are sick, sweat bullets if they don't get home on time when they first have driver's licenses and worry about how to pay for college are the real parents. Elinor S. Prockop Philadelphia

headline.main: Growing Up With Mom and Mom

docs.abstract: Elinor S Prockop letter scores sperm donor who claims paternity of Ry Russo-Young, daughter of lesbian parents (Oct 24 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Island Lady has taken a vacation from it all,'' Tiffani Ross Parker said, pointing to her painting of a woman reclining seaside under a coconut tree and a hot pink sky. ''She's just chillin' all by herself.'' Ms. Parker, who says she suffers from bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, never liked being by herself. When her mother suddenly died in 1992, Ms. Parker, who was 20 at the time, fell apart, reverting to the reckless behavior that cut short her high school education.

docs.lead_paragraph: The government and Unicef reported that up to one in seven babies born in the country -- 5,000 to 7,000 a year -- becomes H.I.V. positive, either during birth or by transmission in breast-feeding. In a progress report on their anti-AIDS efforts, officials stated that babies born to H.I.V.-positive mothers stood a one-in-four to a one-in-three chance of contracting the virus. The growing number of infections has reversed a decline in child mortality, officials said. Currently about one in 10 Lesotho children dies before age 5. Michael Wines (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Lesotho: Rise In H.I.V. Babies

docs.lead_paragraph: A pregnant woman struck by an out-of-control S.U.V. outside a Chinatown church on Oct. 28 has died of her injuries, a spokesman at Bellevue Hospital Center said yesterday. The woman, Zheng Bi Xiang, 34, was crossing Rutgers Street when a Toyota RAV4 drove onto the sidewalk and struck her before flipping on its side and sliding into a group of mourners outside a funeral at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church. She was five months pregnant. The fetus died last Wednesday and the woman died on Friday, the hospital said. The police said that the driver and a passenger, who ran away, turned themselves in later. No charges were filed. Michael Wilson (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pregnant Woman Struck By Car Dies

docs.abstract: Zheng Bi Xiang dies of injuries received when she was struck by out-of-control vehicle in Manhattan's Chinatown section on Oct 28; her five-month-old fetus died on Nov 3; people in car that struck her left scene of accident, but later turned themselves in; no charges have been filed (S)

byline.original: By Michael Wilson (NYT); Compiled by George James

docs.lead_paragraph: In a scene from the movie ''Kinsey,'' opening in theaters on Friday, government agents seize a box of study materials being shipped by Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey, the pioneering sex researcher, and impound the contents as obscene. The scene portrays a time in American history, the 1940's and 1950's, when marital relations were rarely discussed and frank reporting about sex was greeted with a collective anxiety verging on horror. In 1948, when Dr. Kinsey published ''Sexual Behavior in the Human Male,'' he was called a pervert, a menace and even a Communist.

headline.main: Long After Kinsey, Only the Brave Study Sex

docs.abstract: Sex researchers in United States fight uphill battle against conservatives and critics, who say sex studies are inappropriate and could encourage deviant behavior; Dr Alfred Kinsey, pioneer sex researcher who published book Sexual Behavior in the Human Male in 1948, was viewed by many as public threat and some sex researchers today still operate in underground mode fearing reprisals and loss of financing for research; research into pedophilia or other deviant sexual behaviors elicit strongest protests; Dr John Gagnon, State University of New York at Stony Brook sociology professor and author of book An Interpretation of Desire, holds that broader social views on sexuality and sexual preference have made sex research easier than it was when Kinsey was working, but acknowledges that opposition to research is more organized than before; Dr Erick Janssen, Kinsey Institute psychologist, describes his research on risk-taking and sex; other studies discussed; photos; graphs (L)
docs.snippet: Scientists say one thing has remained constant since Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey's work: Americans' ambivalence about the study of sexuality.
